text: What was Amos's occupation before becoming a prophet?
options: Shepherd and dresser of sycamore figs
verseText: The words of Amos, who was among the shepherds of Tekoa... Then Amos answered and said to Amaziah, “I was no prophet, nor a prophet's son, but I was a herdsman and a dresser of sycamore figs.

text: Amos prophesied primarily against which kingdom?
verseText: ...which he saw concerning Israel in the days of Uzziah king of Judah and in the days of Jeroboam the son of Joash, king of Israel...

text: Amos begins his prophecy by pronouncing judgment on several nations surrounding Israel. What is the recurring phrase introducing these judgments?
options: 'For three transgressions of [nation], and for four, I will not revoke the punishment...'
verseText: (Repeated formula introducing judgments on Damascus, Gaza, Tyre, Edom, Ammon, Moab, Judah, and Israel)

text: What were some of the primary sins Amos condemned in Israel?
options: Social injustice, oppressing the poor, empty religious ritualism
verseText: (Examples: 'selling the righteous for silver, and the needy for a pair of sandals'; 'oppress the poor, crush the needy'; 'trample on the poor'; 'take bribes'; God hating their feasts and assemblies)

text: In Amos 5:14, what are the people urged to seek instead of evil?
verseText: Seek good, and not evil, that you may live; and so the LORD, the God of hosts, will be with you, as you have said.

text: What does God say He despises and rejects in Amos 5:21-23?
options: Their feasts, assemblies, offerings, and songs
verseText: “I hate, I despise your feasts, and I take no delight in your solemn assemblies. Even though you offer me your burnt offerings and grain offerings, I will not accept them... Take away from me the noise of your songs; to the melody of your harps I will not listen.

text: Instead of empty rituals, what does God want to 'roll down like waters' in Amos 5:24?
verseText: But let justice roll down like waters, and righteousness like an ever-flowing stream.

text: Amos saw five visions of judgment. Which of these involved a plumb line?
verseText: He showed me this: behold, the Lord was standing beside a wall built with a plumb line, with a plumb line in his hand. And the LORD said to me, “Amos, what do you see?” And I said, “A plumb line.” Then the Lord said, “Behold, I am setting a plumb line in the midst of my people Israel; I will never again pass by them;

text: Who was the priest of Bethel who confronted Amos and told him to stop prophesying in Israel?
verseText: Then Amaziah the priest of Bethel sent to Jeroboam king of Israel, saying, “Amos has conspired against you in the midst of the house of Israel... O seer, go, flee away to the land of Judah, and eat bread there, and prophesy there, but never again prophesy at Bethel...

text: Despite the messages of judgment, how does the book of Amos end?
options: With a promise of future restoration and blessing for David's fallen booth
With a call for more sacrifices
verseText: “In that day I will raise up the booth of David that is fallen and repair its breaches... I will restore the fortunes of my people Israel... I will plant them on their land, and they shall never again be uprooted out of the land that I have given them,” says the LORD your God.

text: According to Amos 1:2, where does the LORD 'roar' from?
verseText: And he said: “The LORD roars from Zion and utters his voice from Jerusalem; the pastures of the shepherds mourn, and the top of Carmel withers.”

text: Which nation was condemned in Amos 1 for 'threshing Gilead with threshing sledges of iron'?
verseText: Thus says the LORD: “For three transgressions of Damascus, and for four, I will not revoke the punishment, because they have threshed Gilead with threshing sledges of iron.

text: What specific sin led to the judgment pronounced on Tyre in Amos 1?
options: Breaking a covenant of brotherhood by selling people into slavery
verseText: Thus says the LORD: “For three transgressions of Tyre, and for four, I will not revoke the punishment, because they delivered up a whole people to Edom, and did not remember the covenant of brotherhood.

text: Edom was condemned primarily for what sin against his 'brother' (Israel/Judah)?
options: Pursuing him with the sword and casting off all pity
verseText: Thus says the LORD: “For three transgressions of Edom, and for four, I will not revoke the punishment, because he pursued his brother with the sword and cast off all pity, and his anger tore perpetually, and he kept his wrath forever.

text: The Ammonites faced judgment for what horrific act mentioned in Amos 1:13?
options: Ripping open pregnant women in Gilead
verseText: Thus says the LORD: “For three transgressions of the Ammonites, and for four, I will not revoke the punishment, because they have ripped open pregnant women in Gilead, that they might enlarge their border.

text: Moab was condemned for what specific act of desecration?
options: Burning the bones of the king of Edom into lime
verseText: Thus says the LORD: “For three transgressions of Moab, and for four, I will not revoke the punishment, because he burned to lime the bones of the king of Edom.

text: What was the primary reason given for God's judgment against Judah in Amos 2?
options: Rejecting the law of the LORD and not keeping His statutes
verseText: Thus says the LORD: “For three transgressions of Judah, and for four, I will not revoke the punishment, because they have rejected the law of the LORD, and have not kept his statutes, but their lies have led them astray...

text: In Amos 3:2, why does God say He will punish Israel for all their iniquities?
options: Because they are weaker than other nations
Because He knew them uniquely ('You only have I known')
Because they failed to pay tribute
verseText: “You only have I known of all the families of the earth; therefore I will punish you for all your iniquities.

text: What rhetorical question does Amos use in 3:3 to illustrate the broken relationship between God and Israel?
options: 'Does a lion roar when it has no prey?'
'Do two walk together, unless they have agreed to meet?'
'Does a bird fall into a snare where there is no trap?'
'Does disaster come to a city, unless the LORD has done it?'
verseText: Do two walk together, unless they have agreed to meet?

text: What does Amos call the wealthy, oppressive women of Samaria in Amos 4:1?
verseText: “Hear this word, you cows of Bashan, who are on the mountain of Samaria, who oppress the poor, who crush the needy, who say to your husbands, ‘Bring, that we may drink!’

text: Which of these was NOT among the judgments God sent on Israel (mentioned in Amos 4) that failed to make them return?
verseText: (Lists famine, drought, blight/mildew, pestilence, and destruction like Sodom/Gomorrah)

text: What is the recurring refrain after each failed judgment described in Amos 4:6-11?
options: 'Yet you did not return to me'
verseText: “...yet you did not return to me,” declares the LORD.

text: After listing the failed corrective judgments, what does God tell Israel to do in Amos 4:12?
verseText: “Therefore thus I will do to you, O Israel; because I will do this to you, prepare to meet your God, O Israel!”

text: What kind of song does Amos raise over Israel in Amos 5:1-2?
verseText: Hear this word that I take up over you in lamentation, O house of Israel: “Fallen, no more to rise, is the virgin Israel; forsaken on her land, with none to raise her up.”

text: In Amos 5:18, what warning does Amos give about the 'Day of the LORD'?
options: It will be darkness, not light
It will only affect the nations
verseText: Woe to you who desire the day of the LORD! Why would you have the day of the LORD? It is darkness, and not light,

text: What does Amos 5:15 urge the people to do in the gate (place of judgment)?
options: Hate evil, love good, and establish justice
verseText: Hate evil, and love good, and establish justice in the gate; it may be that the LORD, the God of hosts, will be gracious to the remnant of Joseph.

text: Amos condemns the Israelites in chapter 6 for being 'at ease' and 'complacent'. Where were these complacent people located?
verseText: “Woe to those who are at ease in Zion, and to those who feel secure on the mountain of Samaria, the notable men of the first of the nations, to whom the house of Israel comes!

text: What luxury items are mentioned in Amos 6:4-6 associated with the complacency of the rich?
options: Beds of ivory, eating lambs/calves, wine, inventing musical instruments
verseText: “Woe to those who lie on beds of ivory and stretch themselves out on their couches, and eat lambs from the flock and calves from the midst of the stall, who sing idle songs to the sound of the harp and like David invent for themselves instruments of music, who drink wine in bowls and anoint themselves with the finest oils...

text: What key characteristic were the complacent rich lacking, according to Amos 6:6?
options: Grief over the ruin of Joseph (Israel)
verseText: ...but are not grieved over the ruin of Joseph!

text: In the first two visions (locusts and fire), what was Amos's response?
options: He interceded, asking God to forgive
He wrote down the vision immediately
verseText: O Lord GOD, please forgive! How can Jacob stand? He is so small!... O Lord GOD, please cease! How can Jacob stand? He is so small!”

text: What did the plumb line in Amos's third vision symbolize?
options: God's standard of righteousness against which Israel was measured
verseText: ...Behold, I am setting a plumb line in the midst of my people Israel; I will never again pass by them;

text: What accusation did Amaziah the priest make against Amos to King Jeroboam II?
verseText: Then Amaziah the priest of Bethel sent to Jeroboam king of Israel, saying, “Amos has conspired against you in the midst of the house of Israel. The land is not able to bear all his words.

text: Where did Amaziah tell Amos to go and prophesy instead of Bethel?
verseText: And Amaziah said to Amos, “O seer, go, flee away to the land of Judah, and eat bread there, and prophesy there;

text: How did Amos respond to Amaziah's command to stop prophesying in Israel?
options: He denied being a professional prophet and pronounced judgment on Amaziah
verseText: Then Amos answered and said to Amaziah, “I was no prophet, nor a prophet's son... but the LORD took me... and the LORD said to me, ‘Go, prophesy to my people Israel.’ Now therefore hear the word of the LORD... your wife shall be a prostitute... your sons and daughters shall fall by the sword... and you yourself shall die in an unclean land...

text: What did the basket of 'summer fruit' (qayits) in Amos's fourth vision symbolize?
verseText: He showed me: behold, a basket of summer fruit... And he said, “Amos, what do you see?” And I said, “A basket of summer fruit.” Then the LORD said to me, “The end has come upon my people Israel; I will never again pass by them.

text: What specific dishonest practices by merchants does Amos condemn in 8:5-6?
options: Making the ephah small, the shekel great, and using false balances
Refusing to sell to the poor
verseText: ...making the ephah small and the shekel great and dealing deceitfully with false balances, that we may buy the poor for silver and the needy for a pair of sandals and sell the chaff of the wheat?”

text: Amos 8:11 prophesies a unique kind of famine. What will people hunger and thirst for?
options: Hearing the words of the LORD
verseText: “Behold, the days are coming,” declares the Lord GOD, “when I will send a famine on the land— not a famine of bread, nor a thirst for water, but of hearing the words of the LORD.

text: In the fifth vision (Amos 9), where is the Lord standing when He commands the destruction?
verseText: I saw the Lord standing beside the altar, and he said: “Strike the capitals until the thresholds shake, and shatter them on the heads of all the people...

text: What does God emphasize about His inescapable judgment in Amos 9:2-4?
options: Only the leaders will be punished
Escape is impossible, even to Sheol, heaven, Carmel, or the sea
Neighboring nations will help Israel hide
verseText: “If they dig into Sheol, from there shall my hand take them; if they climb up to heaven, from there I will bring them down... if they hide from my sight at the bottom of the sea, there I will command the serpent, and it shall bite them.

text: In Amos 9:7, God compares Israel's exodus to the movements of which other peoples?
options: Philistines from Caphtor and Syrians from Kir
verseText: “Are you not like the Cushites to me, O people of Israel?” declares the LORD. “Did I not bring up Israel from the land of Egypt, and the Philistines from Caphtor and the Syrians from Kir?

text: Despite judgment, what structure does God promise to restore in Amos 9:11?
options: The fallen booth (or tabernacle) of David
verseText: “In that day I will raise up the booth of David that is fallen and repair its breaches, and raise up its ruins and rebuild it as in the days of old,

text: What image of agricultural abundance is used in Amos 9:13 to describe the time of restoration?
verseText: “Behold, the days are coming,” declares the LORD, “when the plowman shall overtake the reaper and the treader of grapes him who sows the seed; the mountains shall drip sweet wine, and all the hills shall flow with it.

text: What is the final promise God makes to restored Israel in Amos 9:15?
options: They will never again be uprooted from their land
They will have a new king like David
verseText: I will plant them on their land, and they shall never again be uprooted out of the land that I have given them,” says the LORD your God.

text: During whose reigns did Amos prophesy?
options: Uzziah of Judah and Jeroboam II of Israel
verseText: The words of Amos... which he saw concerning Israel in the days of Uzziah king of Judah and in the days of Jeroboam the son of Joash, king of Israel, two years before the earthquake.

text: What natural disaster is mentioned in Amos 1:1 as a time reference for his prophecy?
verseText: ...two years before the earthquake.
